answers.answer: All test meters should have the capability of being calibrated by the patient for near accurate results. Don't blame the meter. Its up to the patient to thoroughly understand the do's and don'ts of diabetes home testing. Go here for a comparison of well known brands of meters if you are unsure of your brand. http://tinyurl.com/a4g79Different results can be interpreted in various ways;1. Testing after fasting, before meals, or after meals2. Types of foods consumed before testing3. Patients body weight and nutrition4. Meter calibration, whether you're looking at mmol or mg/dl results on the meter.5. Expired and/or contaminated test strips.6. And on and on

question: Why do monitors differ so much in results and how do I knowwhich one would I believe?
title: Meters
